name: 歐洲認同之形塑與演變
description: This course aims to explore the making of European identity through a set of images, practices, visual forms, etc. Europeans have historically created in order to represent the Other. Privileging some areas (Asia) and some manners of appropriation (the narrative; the symbolic emblem) over others, Europeans have conceptualized otherness as an alternative manner of self-definition (“I am what I am because of what I am not”) from the very early dawn of classical civilization. By reviewing some of the most momentous encounters and far-reaching narratives, we will attempt to tease out their meaning and plot it against some of the most influential late 20th century theories of otherness.
goals: to acquire in-depth knowledge with regard to specific issues in the making of European identity
to further internalize the importance of tolerance and mutual respect in intercultural dialogue
to acquire significant familiarity with major theories of intercultural contact in the 20th century
syllabus:
1.      Introduction: major themes and topics; identity and otherness; nation and minority; conceptualizing Europe: outlining the making of an identity

2.      Theoretical models: universalism and relativism; Orientalism

3.      Greek vs Barbarian: absolute or relative?

4.      The Others of classical times: early European cosmographies

5.      Monsters, Jews, Saracens: medieval projections

6.      The exotic other: Prester John; Mandeville; Cathay and the way thither

7.      Learning about the world: the great age of discoveries

8.      Chronicling the Other: Columbus and his journals

9.      Classification and accommodation in the 16th and 17th centuries

10\. Types I: The Turk

11\. Types II: The Chinese

12\. Types III: The Savage

13\. Enlightenment matters: new paradigms of otherness

14\. Inventing the near Other: Eastern Europe

15\. The cult of nations: representation, racism, discrimination

16\. Orientalism, _mode d’emploi_: empire and narrative

17\. Stereotyping the Other in popular culture

      18.Inclusion or exclusion? Problems today
